Carl Strange wrote:

>Colin �
>
>After working through most of the forum messages and considering
>various NEAT environments to work�okay, play�with, I downloaded your
>SharpNEAT.  After a couple of days exploring your code, specifically
>the OCR experiment,  I want to complement you on the nice package you
>have put together.  Very professionally coded and commented.  I was
>particularly impressed you went to the trouble to write alternate
>constructors for many of the classes. This level of quality is tough
>to maintain when working on a tool primarily for one's own benefit or
>learning.
>  
>
[Blush]

Hi Carl,

Thanks for the positive comments. I do try and maintain a certain degree 
of 'quality' in the code I write, so it's nice when folks such as 
yourself pick up on this. I try and hold to the principle that if a 
job's worth doing then it's worth doing properly. A concept that was 
reinforced within me by reading Zen & The Art of Motercycle Maintenance 
a couple of years ago. :) Actually I think about this stuff all the 
time, mainly as a consequence of trying to write software in a 
commercial environment where the concept is somewhat alien. ho hum.

>It's been well over a year since I did anything serious with C# and
>it's nice to get back in tune <wink> with the language.  Like you, I
>think the MS team that designed the language did a very good job of
>cleaning up C++ and the libraries and enjoy working in the C# environment.
>  
>
I was very skeptical of MS at first, but came around in the end. Miguel 
de Icaza (top man at the Mono project) even suggested that .Net could 
become a standard platform for Linux software development.

>Along with the SharpNEAT system, I downloaded the handful of articles
>on the site.  Have you written any "user documentation" along the
>lines of "Design Your Own Experiment" or do I dive in and learn by
>your examples?
>  
>
I haven't but I ought to. I started updating the web site with the 
intention of adding a HOW TO type page, but as is often the way I got 
distracted. In the mean time yeh have a look at the existing 
experiments, hopefully everything should be /reasonably/ easy to 
understand. I recommend you grab the pre-release zip file I posted on 
the list recently, the way experiments are put together was modified to 
allow for co-evolution experiments.

>Thanks for all the work you have contributed.
>
>  
>
Cheers,

Colin.
